title: Zytronic's profits fall £200,000 as value of the pound plummets
text:
Zytronic's profits fall £200,000 as value of the pound plummets Despite the results the Gateshead-based firm is predicting big profit growth in 2017 Share Zytronic CEO Mark Cambridge (Photo: Chris White) Share Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
Touch sensor manufacturer Zytronic has seen its profit before tax fall by 4.4% to £4.3m because of the impact the EU referendum vote had the value of the pound. 
The Blaydon-based company would have seen profits increase to £5.2m but the fall in sterling caused a £900,000 drop in the value of forward exchange contracts. 
Zytronic makes touch screens for equipment such as cashpoints, gaming and vending machines, and household appliances. 
Turnover at the firm fell marginally from £21.3m to £21.1m and the results are less impressive than in 2015 when Zytronic increased its revenue by £3m and its profit by £1.2m. 
Despite the lacklustre results, broker N+1 Singer is forecasting that Zytronic will grow during 2017. It estimates that turnover will grow by 3.8% to £21.9m and profit will soar 25% to £5.4m. Zytronic's profits have suffered as a result of the European Union vote 
Zytronic produces both touch screen and non-touch glass, although the firm has been diversifying away from the latter. Revenue from touch screen glass grew by 5% to £18.2m, while turnover from non-touch glass fell 26% to £2.9m. 
Chief executive Mark Cambridge said: “The plan is continuing along the lines of what we have done and continuing to see greater touch screen production and sales. 
“We also want to drive forward into trying to produce the greater volumes of the larger sized products, which our technology is ideally suited to the development of solutions.” 
Export revenues accounted for 95% of the firm’s total turnover. Although the devaluation of the pound impacted the business’s bottom line, Mr Cambridge said that Brexit could be a benefit for Zytronic. Read More 
He said: “You can either look at it positively or negatively. From the point of view of the levels of sales we have done in Asia and North America, it is more than what we have been doing in Europe . 
“If there were trade barriers dropped in North America and Asia we would have a significant benefit.” 
The business also took advantage of the Patent Box tax rule, which allows companies to apply a lower rate of corporation tax to profits earned from patented inventions. Zytronic has five patents and lowered its total corporation tax bill to 4% for the year. 
Zytronic’s directors proposed a final dividend of 10.96p per share, which is up from 8.87p in 2015. Basic earnings per share stands at 26.6p. Like us on Facebook
